title: 109_hr6254
content: The Act titled "Sentencing Fairness and Equity Restoration Act of 2006" reaffirms Congress' intent in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1984. The Act "Sentencing Fairness and Equity Restoration Act of 2006" amends Section 3553(b) of title 18, United States Code, regarding the imposition of sentences by the court. The "Sentencing Fairness and Equity Restoration Act of 2006" amends Section 3553(b) of title 18, United States Code, allowing the court to impose a sentence above the minimum range, up to the maximum provided in the statute. It also specifies the kind of sentence to be imposed and addresses mitigating circumstances. The "Sentencing Fairness and Equity Restoration Act of 2006" amends Section 3553(b) of title 18, United States Code, allowing the court to impose a sentence above the minimum range, up to the maximum provided in the statute. Section 3553(c) is also amended to require the court to state reasons for imposing a sentence at the time of sentencing. The court must provide a statement of reasons for the sentence imposed, along with a public record, to the Sentencing Commission and Bureau of Prisons. The court of appeals will review sentences below the minimum guideline range de novo, and determine the reasonableness of other sentences. Uniform national standards for downward departures for substantial assistance are outlined in Section 3. The Attorney General must establish a new policy within 180 days regarding motions for departure sentence reductions based on substantial assistance. This policy will define substantial assistance, outline the process for determining it, and establish criteria for the extent of reduction sought by the Government. Additionally, a report to Congress is required within the same timeframe. Upon enactment of this Act, the Attorney General must report to Congress the policy created under subsection (a). Section 994(w)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include exceptions for petty offenses in criminal cases and prohibits delegation of judicial administrative responsibilities to the executive branch.
